title: How to Make a Pringles Can Macro Diffuser

steps.headline: Get your Pringles can.
steps.description: If you want to use other chip brands that come in a can, just make sure it is reflective inside and fairly similar to the Pringles version.

steps.headline: Be sure to clean out your can first.
steps.description: The chips won't do anything for your camera hardware.

steps.headline: Take your flash that you will be using and estimate the size of hole you will need for it.
steps.description: Trace it onto the can. You want to be sure that it is actually going to be a little undersized. You can't put the material you just cut off back on. It is better to work up to the correct size for your flash.

steps.headline: Start cutting it out.
steps.description: Remember, you are cutting it smaller than you will need so it is okay if your cuts are a little crooked. You will be slowly paring it down and straighter.

steps.headline: Keep trimming away at it until you got it right.
steps.description: Here, it is not quite the right size.

steps.headline: Once, you have the correct size cut out, put your flash on your camera, as well as the setup you plan to use it with.
steps.description: Here it is paired with a set of extension tubes and a reversing ring used with a 50mm prime lens (an old one).

steps.headline: Determine the best angle that you desire and mark it on the can.
steps.description: Like before, it doesn't need to be exact, but you will want to cut it out longer than you want. To ensure that the angle remains consistent, use some kind of straight edge.

steps.headline: Start cutting away the bottom.
steps.description: As with the flash, do it piecemeal. Much easier to be more precise if you don't try to do it all in one cut.

steps.headline: Continue until you think you have the right angle and try it out on your macro setup.
Find something to use as the diffuser.
steps.description: If you have something sturdy and translucent, you can fasten it to the inside of the can. If you don't, try something else. In this picture, you see a Walmart bag 'donation'. The scrunchy was just the right size to hold it on securely.

steps.headline: Try it out.
steps.description: Make any alterations that you need to.

Trace it onto the can. You want to be sure that it is actually going to be a little undersized. You can't put the material you just cut off back on. Like before, it doesn't need to be exact, but you will want to cut it out longer than you want. To ensure that the angle remains consistent, use some kind of straight edge. Start cutting away the bottom. As with the flash, do it piecemeal. Much easier to be more precise if you don't try to do it all in one cut. Continue until you think you have the right angle and try it out on your macro setup.  Find something to use as the diffuser. If you have something sturdy and translucent, you can fasten it to the inside of the can. If you don't, try something else. In this picture, you see a Walmart bag 'donation'.
